sn22.123:1.1: At one time Venerable Sāriputta and Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita were staying near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana.
sn22.123:1.2: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita came out of retreat, went to Venerable Sāriputta, bowed, sat down to one side, and said:
sn22.123:2.1: “Reverend Sāriputta, what things should an educated mendicant properly attend to?”
sn22.123:2.2: “An educated mendicant should properly attend to these five grasping aggregates as impermanent … as not-self.
sn22.123:2.4: That is, the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
sn22.123:2.5: An educated mendicant should properly attend to these five grasping aggregates as impermanent … as not-self.
sn22.123:2.6: It’s possible that an educated mendicant who regards the five grasping aggregates in this way will realize the fruit of stream-entry.”
sn22.123:3.1: “But Reverend Sāriputta, what things should a mendicant stream-enterer properly attend to?”
sn22.123:3.2: “A mendicant stream-enterer should properly attend to these five grasping aggregates as impermanent … as not-self.
sn22.123:3.3: It’s possible that a mendicant stream-enterer who regards the five grasping aggregates in this way will realize the fruit of once-return.” …
sn22.123:3.4: “It’s possible that a mendicant once-returner who regards the five grasping aggregates in this way will realize the fruit of non-return.” …
sn22.123:3.5: “It’s possible that a mendicant non-returner who regards the five grasping aggregates in this way will realize the fruit of perfection.” …
sn22.123:4.1: “But Reverend Sāriputta, what things should a perfected one properly attend to?”
sn22.123:4.2: “Reverend Koṭṭhita, a perfected one should properly attend to the five grasping aggregates as impermanent, as suffering, as diseased, as an abscess, as a dart, as misery, as an affliction, as alien, as falling apart, as empty, as not-self.
sn22.123:4.3: A perfected one has nothing more to do, and nothing that needs improvement.
sn22.123:4.4: Still, these things, when developed and cultivated, lead to blissful meditation in the present life, and also to mindfulness and situational awareness.”
